title: How to Convert Radians to Degrees

steps.headline: Know that π radians is equal to 180 degrees.
steps.description: Before you begin the conversion process, you have to know that π radians = 180°, which is equivalent to going halfway around a circle. This is important because you'll be using 180/π as a conversion metric. This is because 1 radians is equal to 180/π degrees.

steps.headline: Multiply the radians by 180/π to convert to degrees.
steps.description:
It's that simple. Let's say you're working with π/12 radians. Then, you've got to multiply it by 180/π and simplify when necessary. Here's how you do it:
π/12 x 180/π =
180π/12π  ÷ 12π/12π =
15°
π/12 radians = 15°

steps.headline: Practice with a few examples.
steps.description:
If you really want to get the hang of it, then try converting from radians to degrees with a few more examples. Here are some other problems you can do:

Example 1: 1/3π radians = π/3 x 180/π = 180π/3π ÷ 3π/3π = 60°

Example 2: 7/4π radians = 7π/4 x 180/π  = 1260π/4π ÷ 4π/4π = 315°

Example 3: 1/2π radians = π /2 x 180/π = 180π /2π ÷ 2π/2π = 90°

steps.headline: Remember that there's a difference between "radians" and "π radians."
steps.description: If you say 2π radians or 2 radians, you are not using the same terms. As you know, 2π radians is equal to 360 degrees, but if you're working with 2 radians, then if you want to convert it to degrees, you will have to calculate 2 x 180/π. You will get 360/π, or 114.5°. This is a different answer because, if you're not working with π radians, the π does not cancel out in the equation and results in a different value.

text:
Know that π radians is equal to 180 degrees. Before you begin the conversion process, you have to know that π radians = 180°, which is equivalent to going halfway around a circle. This is important because you'll be using 180/π as a conversion metric. This is because 1 radians is equal to 180/π degrees. Multiply the radians by 180/π to convert to degrees. It's that simple. Let's say you're working with π/12 radians. Then, you've got to multiply it by 180/π and simplify when necessary. Here's how you do it:
π/12 x 180/π =
180π/12π  ÷ 12π/12π =
15°
π/12 radians = 15° Practice with a few examples. If you really want to get the hang of it, then try converting from radians to degrees with a few more examples. Here are some other problems you can do:

Example 1: 1/3π radians = π/3 x 180/π = 180π/3π ÷ 3π/3π = 60°

Example 2: 7/4π radians = 7π/4 x 180/π  = 1260π/4π ÷ 4π/4π = 315°

Example 3: 1/2π radians = π /2 x 180/π = 180π /2π ÷ 2π/2π = 90° Remember that there's a difference between "radians" and "π radians." If you say 2π radians or 2 radians, you are not using the same terms. As you know, 2π radians is equal to 360 degrees, but if you're working with 2 radians, then if you want to convert it to degrees, you will have to calculate 2 x 180/π. You will get 360/π, or 114.5°. This is a different answer because, if you're not working with π radians, the π does not cancel out in the equation and results in a different value.
sentences: Know that π radians is equal to 180 degrees.
Before you begin the conversion process, you have to know that π radians = 180°, which is equivalent to going halfway around a circle.
This is important because you'll be using 180/π as a conversion metric.
This is because 1 radians is equal to 180/π degrees.
Multiply the radians by 180/π to convert to degrees.
Let's say you're working with π/12 radians.
Then, you've got to multiply it by 180/π and simplify when necessary.

Here's how you do it:
π/12 x 180/π =
180π/12π  ÷ 12π/12π =
15°
π/12 radians = 15° Practice with a few examples.
If you really want to get the hang of it, then try converting from radians to degrees with a few more examples.

Here are some other problems you can do:

Example 1: 1/3π radians = π/3 x 180/π = 180π/3π ÷ 3π/3π = 60°

Example 2: 7/4π radians = 7π/4 x 180/π  = 1260π/4π ÷ 4π/4π = 315°

Example 3: 1/2π radians = π /2 x 180/π = 180π /2π ÷ 2π/2π = 90° Remember that there's a difference between "radians" and "π radians."
If you say 2π radians or 2 radians, you are not using the same terms.
As you know, 2π radians is equal to 360 degrees, but if you're working with 2 radians, then if you want to convert it to degrees, you will have to calculate 2 x 180/π.
This is a different answer because, if you're not working with π radians, the π does not cancel out in the equation and results in a different value.
